Photoconductivity in highly tetrahedral diamondlike amorphous carbon 
G. A. J. Amaratunga, V. S. Veerasamy, W. I. Milne, C. A. Davis,a) S. R. P. Silva, 
and H. S. MacKenzie 
Department of Engineering, Cambridge University, Trumpington Street, 
Cambridge CBZ IPZ, United Kingdom 
(Received 21 January 1993; accepted for publication 15 May 1993) 
A photoconductive effect is observed in tetrahedral amorphous carbon (ta-C) or amorphous 
diamond films with a high proportion of sp3 bonding and a structure analogous to amorphous 
silicon. The spectral response is shown to peak at around 750400 nm and extend into the near 
UV region. The maximum photoresponse coincides wit.h the optical absorption edge. The 
quantum efficiency of 300 nm thick films with interdigitated electrodes is over 10% in the 
wavelength range 450400 nm. 
There is presently great interest in hydrogen-free tet- 
rahedral amorphous carbon (WC) because of its high di- 
amondlike sp3-bonded carbon content (70%~85%) com- 
pared to other amorphous carbon films. This bonding gives 
ta-C many valuable properties such as high mechanical 
hardness, low friction, and chemical inertness.’ ta-C is also 
a semiconductor with an optical band gap in the range of 
1.65-2.0 eV.’ The coupling of optical absorption and space 
charge limited current flow results have shown the density 
of states at the valence band edge to be of the order of 10” 
cm- ’ eV-*, decreasing exponentially to lOi8 cm 3 eV ~ * at 
0.4 eV from the valence band edge.” The ta-C films used in 
this work were deposited using a cathodic vacuum arc and 
are optically smooth, pin hole free and can be grown over 
areas up to 10 cm2 at relatively low temperatures 
( < 60 “C). The cathodic arc is a low voltage, high current 
discharge in which the current is concentrated at one or 
more micron-sized cathode spots.4 The extremely high cur- 
rent densities at the cathode spot cause rapid evaporation 
of the solid cathode material, most of which is ionized in 
an intense plasma associated with the cathode spots. In the 
case of a carbon cathode (ultra-pure graphite), the emitted 
ions are primarily C+ and C2+ ions.’ The cathodic arc 
plasma stream is passed through a magnetic torus to filter 
out the macroparticles and neutrals. This ensures that only 
carbon ions impinge on the substrate to form thin films of 
ta-C. The substrate can be left at floating potential or if 
conducting can be biased negatively to increase the carbon 
ion energies. Thin films of ta-C ranging from 100 to 300 
nm in thickness were grown on LPCVD grown silicon 
nitride and fused quartz substrates under floating potential. 
Under t.hese conditions, the average energy of the carbon 
ions is equal to the energy with which they are emitted 
from the cathode, i.e., about 20 eV. A deposit.ion rate of 
about 3 rim/s was achieved with a nominal magnetic field 
strength of 60 mT. The arc voltage and current were 20 V 
and 40 A, respectively, during deposition. Structural char- 
acterization of the films deposited under these conditions 
was carried out using a transmission electron microscope 
(TEM) fitted with an electron energy loss spectroscopy 
attachment. Diffuse rings typical of amorphous materials 
were observed in the diffraction patterns of the films. A 
plasmon peak of about 30 eV and an $-bonded carbon 
content of approximately 70% was measured.3 
Interdigitated gap-cell struttures consisting of 100 nm 
thick, 5 mm long gold contacts with spacings of 50 /Lrn 
were patterned on the ta-C films using photolithography. A 
programmable voltage source was then connected to the 
gold contacts and the current passing through the ta-C film 
was monitored using a Keithley picoammeter with a sen- 
sitivity of the order of 10 l3 A. All electrical measure- 
ments were carried out in the plane of the films. The 
current-voltage characteristics of the ta-C gap cells under 
dark and light conditions are shown in Fig. 1. An AM1 
fiber optic light source was used for head-on illumination 
in both continuous and pulsed modes. Symmetrical 1-V 
curves measured with change in voltage polarity confirmed 
the ohmic nature of the contacts. The current increase of 
one to two orders of magnitude when the structures were 
exposed to light corresponds to a decrease in the resistivity 
of ta-C films from lo7 to 10’ lZ cm. This is attributed to a 
photoconductive erect in ta-C films. 
The spectral response of the ta-C thin films was mon- 
itored over the wavelength range 350-1050 nm. The pho-

characterized by focusing light in the 350-1050 nm wave- 
length range. The source of radiation was a tungsten lamp 
in conjunction with a spectrometer with 800 line/mm grat- 
ings blazed at 1 pm intervals. The spectral resolution of the 
system was 5 nm. The responsivity and external quantum 
efficiency of the ta-C photoconductor was obtained by 
comparison with a standard of known responsivity, a super 
UV series 7 photodiode. Satisfactory agreement was ob- 
tained between the average photodiode calibration curve 
provided by the manufacturer and the responsivity calibra- 
tion on the specific diode done in our laboratory. The spec- 
tral response curves for films with thicknesses 100 and 300 
nm are shown in Fig. 2. The incident light was chopped at 
100 Hz and the ac component of the photocurrent response 
was measured using a lock-in amplifier. 
The external quantum efficiency versus wavelength 
curves for the two samples of different thicknesses are also 
shown on Fig. 2. The illuminated areas of the photocon- 
ductor and the silicon diode used for calibration were kept 
constant, equal to 8 mm2. Noteworthy features of the re- 
sponsivity versus wavelength curves are: 
(i) The responsivity curves for both samples show a 
pronounced peak at about 700-800 nm, corresponding to 
photon energies between 1.6 and 1.8 eV; 
(ii) the photoresponse extends into the blue-green re- 
gion of the spectrum; 
(iii) the quantum efficiency of the 300 nm thick ta-C 
films lies between 10% and 12.5% in the 450-800 nm 
wavelength range. The optical band gap of the ta-C depos- 
ited on fused quartz is determined to be in the range of 
1.8-2.2 eV from the Taut plot of the transmission spec- 
trum. The maximum photoresponse at 750-800 nm is 
found to coincide with the absorption edge. The value of 
the absorption coefficient a for the films is greater than lo4 
cm- ’ from 750 to 400 nm, Fig. 3. 
The current activation energy of the films was also 
monitored in the dark and under white light. The dark 
conductivity as a function of temperature is shown in Fig. 
4. The dark conductivity cd increases with increasing tem- 
perature following the Mott-Twose relationship cd 
=o(O)exp( -E&W) suggesting activation of carriers 
into the extended states. This gives an activation energy E, 
of 0.2-0.25 eV above the valence band, if one assumes that 
the as-deposited ta-C is weakly p type.3 On the other hand, 
the variation of conductivity under light was found to be 
independent of temperature, curve (b) in Fig. 3. This re- 
sult is in accordance with conductivity under light aPh be- 
ing dominated by the generation term in the expression 
cPh=od+pOGr, thus showing that the mobility lifetime 
(~~7) product is temperature independent (in the range 
considered) for a given bulk photogeneration rate G in 
ta-C films. 
. 
In the interpretation of the photoconductive results it 
is reasonable to assume that the photogenerated current is 
predominantly carried by electrons in the extended states 
of the conduction band. In this scheme electrons are ex- 
cited from the extended states in the valence band or from 
filled localized tail states near the valence band edge. The 
spectral response of photoconductivity, therefore, reveals 
information regarding the electronic band gap (mobility 
gap) of this amorphous semiconductor since the mobility 
gap should be larger than the optical band gap. The occur- 
rence of a shoulder in the responsivity at photon energies in

In summary, hydrogen-free ta-C films deposited from a 
filtered vacuum arc source display photoconductivity. The 
spectral response of the thin films shows that this material 
has an electronic band gap equal to or greater than 1.6 eV. 
The interdigitated photoconductors are found to have a 
quantum efficiency of over 10% in the wavelength range
